name: Ford
title: Multiple AI Subsidiaries with Structural Division Separation

classification.classificationRationale: Ford exhibits classic M4 Hybrid/Hub-and-Spoke with multiple distributed AI units operating with significant autonomy: Latitude AI (550-person autonomous driving subsidiary), Greenfield Labs (~300 researchers in Palo Alto), FARIC (Atlanta software/AI center), and a Doug Field-led skunkworks for affordable EVs. The Ford+ restructuring that separated Model e (EVs), Ford Blue (ICE), and Ford Pro (commercial) represents textbook structural ambidexterity—exploration and execution physically and organizationally separated. Latitude AI operates as a wholly owned subsidiary with its own C-suite, which is unusual even for M4 organizations. The skunkworks under Doug Field adds an M8 secondary element for radical EV innovation.

description:
Ford operates one of the most distributed AI structures in the automotive industry, with multiple specialized units pursuing different AI applications at varying time horizons. The flagship AI unit is Latitude AI, a 550-person wholly owned subsidiary headquartered in Pittsburgh focused on hands-free, eyes-off automated driving technology. Unlike most corporate AI labs, Latitude operates with its own CEO (Sammy Omari), CTO (Peter Carr), and President (David Gollob)—a level of structural independence typically reserved for true spin-offs.

The company's broader AI structure includes Greenfield Labs in Palo Alto (~300 researchers focused on human-centered design), FARIC in Atlanta (software and digital transformation), and a skunkworks unit under Doug Field (ex-Apple, Tesla) developing affordable EVs. This distributed model reflects Ford's 2022 Ford+ restructuring, which separated the company into Model e (EVs), Ford Blue (ICE vehicles), and Ford Pro (commercial)—a structural ambidexterity approach that physically separates exploration from execution.

CEO Jim Farley frames AI primarily through a workforce impact lens, warning that AI will 'replace literally half of all white-collar workers' while advocating for AI to 'supercharge' essential economy workers rather than replace them. This philosophical stance positions Ford's AI strategy as much about workforce transformation as product innovation, with a focus on deploying AI 'systemically across the entire industrial system' rather than just in vehicles.

observableMarkers.reportingStructure: Latitude AI operates as wholly owned subsidiary with own C-suite (CEO, CTO, President). Doug Field as Chief Advanced Product Development Officer suggests AI/advanced tech reports to a product-focused executive rather than CIO/CTO. Ford Credit has Head of Non-Risk AI/ML and Gen AI reporting to Ford Credit CTO. Decentralized structure across Model e, Ford Blue, and Ford Pro divisions.
observableMarkers.resourceAllocation: Dedicated subsidiary for autonomous driving (Latitude AI). Separate innovation centers in Palo Alto, Atlanta, and Dearborn. Ring-fenced EV/skunkworks development under Doug Field. Strong cash position ($33B cash, $54B liquidity) enables continued investment.
observableMarkers.timeHorizons: Short-term: Deploying AI across industrial system, quality improvements, warranty process optimization. Medium-term: BlueCruise expansion and enhancement. Long-term: Hands-free, eyes-off-road automated driving via Latitude AI (5-10 year horizon).
observableMarkers.decisionRights: Distributed across divisions (Model e, Blue, Pro) and specialized units (Latitude AI, Greenfield Labs). Central R&D sets standards while subsidiaries/centers have operational autonomy.
observableMarkers.metrics: BlueCruise miles driven (50M+), quality improvement metrics, cost reduction targets ($1B/year), employee productivity, technician training effectiveness.

mechanisms.name: Protect Off-Strategy Work
mechanisms.evidence: Latitude AI operates as a wholly owned subsidiary with its own C-suite, physically headquartered in Pittsburgh away from Dearborn. This structural independence protects the long-horizon autonomous driving work from quarterly pressures of the core auto business. Doug Field's skunkworks for affordable EVs similarly operates with ring-fenced resources.

taxonomyFeedback: [2026-02] Ford's Latitude AI represents an unusually autonomous M4 spoke—operating as a wholly owned subsidiary with its own CEO, CTO, and President is rare for corporate AI units. This creates a structural independence that borders on M5b (Venture Builder) but without the intent to spin off. The taxonomy may need to distinguish between 'subsidiary autonomy' and 'division autonomy' within M4.

[2026-02] CEO Farley's public framing of AI is almost entirely about workforce transformation rather than product/technology. His 'essential economy' thesis—that AI will devastate white-collar work while skilled trades become more valuable—is a distinctive strategic narrative that shapes how Ford positions its AI investments. This workforce-centric framing is rare among automotive CEOs.

[2026-02] The Ford+ restructuring (Model e/Blue/Pro separation) combined with multiple innovation centers (Latitude AI, Greenfield Labs, FARIC, skunkworks) creates a nested structural ambidexterity: exploration vs. execution separated at both the division level AND within the innovation portfolio. This 'ambidexterity within ambidexterity' pattern may warrant taxonomic attention.
